animals.name: Tiger
facts: Tigers are the largest cat species in the world.
Tigers can reach speeds of up to 60 km/h (37 mph).
A group of tigers is known as a 'streak' or an 'ambush'.
Tigers have been known to swim up to 6 km (3.7 miles) in a single day.
The stripes on a tiger's coat are unique to each individual and can be used to identify them.
Tigers have excellent night vision and can see up to six times better than humans in low light conditions.
A tiger's roar can be heard up to 3 km (1.9 miles) away.
Tigers have been known to attack crocodiles and even swim with them in the water.

animals.name: Elephant
facts: Elephants can live up to 70 years in the wild.
Elephants have a highly developed sense of smell and can detect water sources from miles away.
Elephants can communicate with each other using infrasonic sounds that are below the range of human hearing.
Elephants are the largest land animals in the world.
Elephants have been observed using tools, such as using sticks to scratch an itch or swat a fly.
A group of elephants is known as a 'herd' or a 'parade'.
Elephants have a long memory and can remember other elephants and places they have been for many years.
An elephant's trunk contains around 100,000 muscles.
Elephants can weigh up to 22,000 pounds (10,000 kg).
Elephants have thick skin that can be up to 1 inch (2.5 cm) thick.
Elephants have very good memories and are known to grieve for their dead.
Female elephants live in family groups led by the oldest female, called the matriarch.
Elephants can communicate using a variety of sounds, including trumpets, growls, and grunts.
Elephants are the largest land animals in the world.
Elephants can communicate with each other using infrasonic sounds that are below the range of human hearing.
Elephants are highly intelligent and have been observed showing empathy and grieving the loss of their family members.

animals.name: Giraffe
facts: Giraffes have long necks to help them reach leaves on tall trees.
Giraffes can grow up to 6 meters (20 feet) tall.
Giraffes only need to sleep for around 4 hours per day.
Giraffes are the tallest land animals in the world.
Giraffes have a specially adapted circulatory system that prevents them from passing out when they bend down to drink water.
Giraffes have a blue-black tongue that is around 45 cm (18 inches) long.
Giraffes can run at speeds of up to 60 km/h (37 mph).
Giraffes are the tallest mammals on Earth.
Giraffes can grow up to 18 feet (5.5 meters) tall.
Giraffes have long necks that contain the same number of vertebrae as humans (7).
Giraffes have very long tongues that can reach up to 18 inches (45 cm) long.
Giraffes are herbivores and spend most of their day eating leaves from trees.
Giraffes have a unique spotted pattern on their skin that is different for each individual.
Giraffes can run up to speeds of 35 mph (56 km/h).
Giraffes are social animals and live in groups called towers or herds.
Giraffes are the tallest mammals on Earth.
Giraffes only need to drink once every few days because they get most of their water from the plants they eat.
Giraffes have incredibly long tongues, which can be up to 18 inches long.
Giraffes are the tallest animals in the world, with some reaching up to 18 feet tall.
Giraffes have long necks that contain only seven vertebrae, which are elongated to support their massive head.
Giraffes have a blue-black tongue that can be up to 18 inches long.
Giraffes are social animals that live in herds and communicate through a variety of sounds and body language.

animals.name: Penguin
facts: Penguins are flightless birds that live almost exclusively in the Southern Hemisphere.
Penguins can hold their breath for up to 20 minutes underwater.
Penguins are excellent swimmers and can swim at speeds of up to 22 mph (35 km/h).
Penguins are social animals and live in large colonies.
Some penguin species can jump up to 6 feet (1.8 meters) out of the water.
Penguins have an oil gland above their tail that they use to waterproof their feathers.
Penguins can survive in extreme temperatures, with some species living in temperatures as low as -60°C (-76°F).
Penguins have an organ above their eyes that converts seawater into fresh water.
Penguins are flightless birds that live in Antarctica and other cold regions.
Penguins have a thick layer of feathers that keeps them warm in cold temperatures.
Penguins are excellent swimmers and can dive up to depths of 500 feet (150 meters).
Penguins are carnivores and mainly feed on fish and krill.
Penguins are flightless birds that can swim up to 22 mph.
Penguins huddle together in large groups to keep warm in cold temperatures.
Penguins have a layer of fat called blubber that keeps them warm in cold water.
Penguins are flightless birds that are adapted to living in extreme cold environments.
Penguins have a layer of insulating feathers, a thick layer of blubber, and a counter-current heat exchange system that helps them survive in the harsh conditions.
Penguins mate for life and share parenting duties, with the male taking care of the egg while the female goes to find food.
Penguins are excellent swimmers, with some species able to dive up to 1,800 feet deep.

animals.name: Lion
facts: Lions are the only cats that live in groups called 'prides'.
Lions can run at speeds of up to 50 mph (80 km/h).
Lions are the second largest big cat species in the world, after tigers.
Lions are the only cats that live in groups, called prides.
A lion's roar can be heard up to 5 miles away.
Lions are the second-largest big cat species in the world, after tigers.

animals.name: Octopus
facts: Octopuses can change the color, pattern, and texture of their skin to blend in with their surroundings.
Octopuses have three hearts.
Octopuses have eight arms and no bones in their body.
Octopuses are considered one of the most intelligent invertebrates in the world.
Octopuses can change the color and texture of their skin to blend in with their surroundings.
Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood.
Octopuses are carnivores and feed on crabs, clams, and fish.
Octopuses can squeeze through very small spaces due to their soft, flexible bodies.
Octopuses have excellent eyesight and can see polarized light.
Octopuses are solitary creatures and only come together to mate.
Octopuses have the ability to change color and texture to blend in with their surroundings or communicate with each other.
Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood.
Octopuses are highly intelligent and have been known to solve complex puzzles and escape from aquariums.
Octopuses can regenerate lost limbs and even grow new ones.

animals.name: Kangaroo
facts: Kangaroos can jump up to three times their own body length in one leap.
Kangaroos can hop at speeds of up to 60 km/h (37 mph).
Kangaroos are marsupials that live in Australia.
Kangaroos have powerful hind legs that allow them to hop long distances.
Kangaroos are herbivores and mainly eat grass and plants.
Female kangaroos have a pouch on their belly where they carry their young, called joeys.
Kangaroos are able to go long periods of time without drinking water.
Kangaroos are social animals and live in groups called mobs or troops.
Kangaroos have a unique way of reproducing called embryonic diapause, where they can delay the development of their fetus until environmental conditions are more favorable.
Kangaroos have a lifespan of up to 6 years in the wild and up to 20 years in captivity.
Kangaroos are marsupials that are native to Australia.
Kangaroos have powerful hind legs and use their tail as a 'third leg' to balance while hopping.
Kangaroos can hop at speeds up to 56 km/h (35 mph).
Female kangaroos have a pouch on their belly where they carry and nurse their young, called joeys.
A group of kangaroos is called a mob or troop.
Kangaroos can jump up to three times their own body length.
Kangaroos have powerful hind legs that they use for jumping and for kicking potential predators.
Female kangaroos have a pouch on their belly, which they use to carry and nurse their young.
Kangaroos are the only large animal that uses hopping as their primary means of locomotion.
Kangaroos have powerful hind legs and a long tail that helps them balance.
Kangaroos can jump up to three times their own body length in one leap.
Kangaroos are marsupials and their young, called joeys, develop outside of the mother's body in a pouch.

animals.name: Gorilla
facts: Gorillas have unique nose prints that can be used to identify them, just like human fingerprints.
Gorillas can catch human colds and flu.
Gorillas are the largest primates and are native to Africa.
Gorillas have opposable thumbs and can use tools in the wild.
Gorillas live in groups called troops, led by a dominant male called a silverback.
Silverback gorillas can weigh up to 200 kg (440 lbs) and stand up to 1.8 m (6 ft) tall.
Gorillas are herbivores and mainly eat leaves, shoots, and fruits.

animals.name: Flamingo
facts: Flamingos are pink because of the pigments in the algae and crustaceans they eat.

animals.name: Hippopotamus
facts: Hippos can hold their breath for up to five minutes underwater.
Hippos are large semi-aquatic mammals native to Africa.
Despite their size, hippos can run up to 30 km/h (19 mph) on land.
Hippos are known for their aggressive behavior and are considered one of the most dangerous animals in Africa.
Hippos are herbivores and mainly eat grass.
Hippos can hold their breath for up to five minutes while submerged in water.

animals.name: Koala
facts: Koalas sleep up to 20 hours a day because their diet of eucalyptus leaves is low in energy.

animals.name: Jellyfish
facts: Jellyfish have no brain, heart, or bones, and they are made up of more than 95% water.

animals.name: Chimpanzee
facts: Chimpanzees can recognize themselves in mirrors, a sign of self-awareness.
Chimpanzees can use tools to solve problems and even make other tools.
Chimpanzees share over 98% of their DNA with humans.
Chimpanzees are the only non-human animal that can recognize themselves in the mirror.
Chimpanzees use tools to accomplish tasks, such as using sticks to extract insects from trees or using rocks to crack open nuts.
Chimpanzees live in social groups and have complex communication systems that involve body language, vocalizations, and facial expressions.

animals.name: Ostrich
facts: Ostriches have the largest eyes of any land animal and can see up to 2.5 miles away.

animals.name: Sloth
facts: Sloths only defecate once a week and can lose up to a third of their body weight in the process.
Sloths are arboreal mammals that are native to Central and South America.
Sloth are known for their slow movement and can sleep up to 20 hours a day.
Sloths have a specialized stomach with multiple chambers that allows them to digest tough leaves.
Sloth have long claws that they use to cling to tree branches.
Sloths come down from trees to defecate, which only happens once a week.
Sloths are arboreal animals that spend most of their lives hanging upside down from trees.
Sloth move very slowly and only come down from trees once a week to defecate.
Sloths have a unique symbiotic relationship with algae and moths that live in their fur and help to camouflage them in their environment.
Their slow metabolism and low-energy diet of leaves means that they only need to defecate once a week.

animals.name: Orangutan
facts: Orangutans are the largest tree-dwelling animals in the world.

animals.name: Peregrine falcon
facts: Peregrine falcons are the fastest animals in the world.
Peregrine falcons can reach speeds of up to 240 miles per hour when diving to catch prey.
Peregrine falcons are found on every continent except Antarctica.

animals.name: Blue whale
facts: Blue whales are the largest animals on Earth.
Blue whales can weigh up to 200 tons and grow up to 100 feet in length.
Despite their massive size, blue whales feed mostly on tiny shrimp-like creatures called krill.

animals.name: Komodo Dragon
facts: The Komodo dragon is the largest lizard in the world, growing up to 10 feet long and weighing up to 330 pounds.
Komodo dragons have a venomous bite that can kill their prey within hours.
Komodo dragons are native to Indonesia, specifically the islands of Komodo, Rinca, Flores, Gili Motang, and Padar.
Komodo dragons have a keen sense of smell and can detect carrion from up to 5 miles away.

animals.name: Pangolin
facts: Pangolins are the only mammals in the world covered in scales.
Pangolins are native to Africa and Asia and are highly endangered due to poaching and habitat destruction.
Pangolins have a long, sticky tongue that can be up to 16 inches long, which they use to catch ants and termites.
Pangolins can curl up into a ball to protect themselves from predators.

animals.name: Axolotl
facts: Axolotls are also known as the 'walking fish', but they are actually a type of salamander.
Axolotls are able to regenerate lost limbs, spinal cords, and even parts of their brain.
Axolotls are native to Mexico, but their populations have been greatly impacted by pollution and habitat destruction.

animals.name: Quokka
facts: Quokkas are small marsupials found only on Rottnest Island, Western Australia.
Quokkas are known for their friendly demeanor and often referred to as the 'world's happiest animal'.
Quokkas are herbivores and feed mainly on leaves, bark, and grass.

animals.name: Okapi
facts: Okapis are the only living relative of the giraffe.
Okapis have a long, prehensile tongue, which they use to strip leaves from trees.
Okapis are native to the dense rainforests of the Democratic Republic of Congo.

animals.name: Fennec Fox
facts: Fennec foxes have huge ears, which help them regulate their body temperature and locate prey.
Fennec foxes are the smallest species of fox, and their fur is adapted for life in the desert.
Fennec foxes can go for long periods without water, getting moisture from their food instead.

animals.name: Tarsier
facts: Tarsiers are small primates found in Southeast Asia.
Tarsier have huge eyes that are each larger than their brain.
Tarsiers are carnivorous and have a specialized neck that allows them to rotate their head 180 degrees in search of prey.

animals.name: Red Panda
facts: Red pandas are native to the Himalayas and southwestern China.
Red pandas are arboreal and spend most of their lives in trees.
Red pandas have a 'false thumb' on their front paws, which helps them grip bamboo shoots and other food.

animals.name: Narwhal
facts: Narwhals are a type of whale found in the Arctic Ocean.
Males narwhales have a long, spiral tusk that can grow up to 10 feet long.
Narwhals can dive to depths of up to 1.5 kilometers in search of food.

animals.name: Brown Bear
facts: The brown bear is the largest carnivore in Europe, and can weigh up to 700 kg (1543 lbs).
They have a keen sense of smell and can detect prey up to 20 km (12 miles) away.
Brown bears hibernate during the winter months, and can survive up to six months without eating, drinking, urinating or defecating.
The brown bear is the largest land predator in Europe.
They have a very keen sense of smell and can detect prey from over a kilometer away.
Brown bears are excellent climbers and can easily scale trees to escape danger or access food.

animals.name: Grey Wolf
facts: Grey wolves are highly social animals that live in packs, which can range in size from 2 to 30 individuals.
They are excellent hunters, with a success rate of up to 50% when hunting in packs.
Wolves have a highly developed sense of hearing, which allows them to locate prey from up to 3 km (1.9 miles) away.

animals.name: Eurasian Lynx
facts: The Eurasian lynx is the largest of the four lynx species, and can weigh up to 38 kg (84 lbs).
They are solitary animals that are highly adapted to hunting in dense forests.
Lynx have large, furry paws that act as snowshoes, allowing them to walk on top of deep snow and hunt in winter.
Eurasian lynx are the largest of the four lynx species and are found in many European countries.
They are solitary animals and only come together to mate.
Eurasian lynx are excellent hunters and can bring down prey much larger than themselves.

animals.name: Red fox
facts: Red foxes are the most widely distributed carnivore in the world, found in every continent except Antarctica.
They are very adaptable animals and can survive in a wide range of habitats, from forests and grasslands to urban areas.
Red foxes have excellent senses, including a keen sense of smell and excellent hearing, which they use to locate prey.

animals.name: European bison
facts: The European bison is the largest land animal in Europe.
They were hunted to extinction in the wild in the early 20th century, but have since been reintroduced in several countries.
European bison are herbivores and can eat up to 32 kg of grass and hay in a day.

animals.name: European otter
facts: European otters are very social animals and live in family groups.
They have a layer of waterproof fur that keeps them warm and dry in the water.
European otters are expert swimmers and can hold their breath for up to eight minutes.

animals.name: Goat
facts: Goats are social animals and prefer to live in groups called herds.
Goats can be trained to pull carts and wagons.
Goats have rectangular pupils that give them a panoramic view of their surroundings.

animals.name: Donkey
facts: Donkeys are highly intelligent and can recognize other donkeys from their calls.
Donkeys can live up to 50 years.
Donkeys are known for their stubbornness, but they are actually cautious and will not do something that could harm themselves.

animals.name: Dolphin
facts: Dolphins are highly social animals and often live in groups called pods.
Dolphins are known for their intelligence and ability to learn new tasks quickly.
Dolphins use echolocation to locate objects and communicate with each other.
